declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Alt` type class identifies an associative operation on a type
constructor.  It is similar to `Semigroup`, except that it applies to
types of kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types
`String` or `Number`.

`Alt` instances are required to satisfy the following laws:

- Associativity: `(x <|> y) <|> z == x <|> (y <|> z)`
- Distributivity: `f <$> (x <|> y) == (f <$> x) <|> (f <$> y)`

For example, the `Array` (`[]`) type is an instance of `Alt`, where
`(<|>)` is defined to be concatenation.
declarations.title: Alt

declarations.comments:
The `Alt` type class identifies an associative operation on a type
constructor.  It is similar to `Semigroup`, except that it applies to
types of kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types
`String` or `Number`.

`Alt` instances are required to satisfy the following laws:

- Associativity: `(x <|> y) <|> z == x <|> (y <|> z)`
- Distributivity: `f <$> (x <|> y) == (f <$> x) <|> (f <$> y)`

For example, the `Array` (`[]`) type is an instance of `Alt`, where
`(<|>)` is defined to be concatenation.
declarations.title: Alt

declarations.comments:
The `Applicative` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class
with a `pure` function, which can be used to create values of type `f a`
from values of type `a`.

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or
more arguments to functions whose arguments are wrapped using `f`, and
[`Functor`](#functor) provides the ability to lift functions of one
argument, `pure` can be seen as the function which lifts functions of
_zero_ arguments. That is, `Applicative` functors support a lifting
operation for any number of function arguments.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action when a condition is true.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action unless a condition is true.
declarations.title: unless

declarations.comments:
`liftA1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Applicative`](#applicative) functor, without using `(<$>)` as provided
by the [`Functor`](#functor)-[`Applicative`](#applicative) superclass
relationship.

`liftA1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftA1
```
declarations.title: liftA1

declarations.comments:
The `Apply` class provides the `(<*>)` which is used to apply a function
to an argument under a type constructor.

`Apply` can be used to lift functions of two or more arguments to work on
values wrapped with the type constructor `f`. It might also be understood
in terms of the `lift2` function:

```purescript
lift2 :: forall f a b c. Apply f => (a -> b -> c) -> f a -> f b -> f c
lift2 f a b = f <$> a <*> b
```

`(<*>)` is recovered from `lift2` as `lift2 ($)`. That is, `(<*>)` lifts
the function application operator `($)` to arguments wrapped with the
type constructor `f`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Functor`
laws:

- Associative composition: `(<<<) <$> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`

Formally, `Apply` represents a strong lax semi-monoidal endofunctor.
declarations.title: Apply

declarations.comments:
The `Plus` type class extends the `Alt` type class with a value that
should be the left and right identity for `(<|>)`.

It is similar to `Monoid`, except that it applies to types of
kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types like
`String` or `Number`.

`Plus` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Left identity: `empty <|> x == x`
- Right identity: `x <|> empty == x`
- Annihilation: `f <$> empty == empty`
declarations.title: Plus

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Alternative` type class has no members of its own; it just specifies
that the type constructor has both `Applicative` and `Plus` instances.

Types which have `Alternative` instances should also satisfy the following
laws:

- Distributivity: `(f <|> g) <*> x == (f <*> x) <|> (g <*> x)`
- Annihilation: `empty <*> f = empty`
declarations.title: Alternative

declarations.comments:
The `Extend` class defines the extension operator `(<<=)`
which extends a local context-dependent computation to
a global computation.

`Extend` is the dual of `Bind`, and `(<<=)` is the dual of
`(>>=)`.

Laws:

- Associativity: `extend f <<< extend g = extend (f <<< extend g)`
declarations.title: Extend

declarations.comments:
Duplicate a comonadic context.

`duplicate` is dual to `Control.Bind.join`.
declarations.title: duplicate

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
`Comonad` extends the `Extend` class with the `extract` function
which extracts a value, discarding the comonadic context.

`Comonad` is the dual of `Monad`, and `extract` is the dual of `pure`.

Laws:

- Left Identity: `extract <<= xs = xs`
- Right Identity: `extract (f <<= xs) = f xs`
declarations.title: Comonad

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Extend` class defines the extension operator `(<<=)`
which extends a local context-dependent computation to
a global computation.

`Extend` is the dual of `Bind`, and `(<<=)` is the dual of
`(>>=)`.

Laws:

- Associativity: `extend f <<< extend g = extend (f <<< extend g)`
declarations.title: Extend

declarations.comments: A version of `extend` with its arguments flipped.
declarations.title: extendFlipped

declarations.comments: Forwards co-Kleisli composition.
declarations.title: composeCoKleisli

declarations.comments: Backwards co-Kleisli composition.
declarations.title: composeCoKleisliFlipped

declarations.comments:
Duplicate a comonadic context.

`duplicate` is dual to `Control.Bind.join`.
declarations.title: duplicate

declarations.comments:
The `Lazy` class represents types which allow evaluation of values
to be _deferred_.

Usually, this means that a type contains a function arrow which can
be used to delay evaluation.
declarations.title: Lazy

declarations.comments:
`fix` defines a value as the fixed point of a function.

The `Lazy` instance allows us to generate the result lazily.
declarations.title: fix

declarations.comments:
The `Alt` type class identifies an associative operation on a type
constructor.  It is similar to `Semigroup`, except that it applies to
types of kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types
`String` or `Number`.

`Alt` instances are required to satisfy the following laws:

- Associativity: `(x <|> y) <|> z == x <|> (y <|> z)`
- Distributivity: `f <$> (x <|> y) == (f <$> x) <|> (f <$> y)`

For example, the `Array` (`[]`) type is an instance of `Alt`, where
`(<|>)` is defined to be concatenation.
declarations.title: Alt

declarations.comments:
The `Alternative` type class has no members of its own; it just specifies
that the type constructor has both `Applicative` and `Plus` instances.

Types which have `Alternative` instances should also satisfy the following
laws:

- Distributivity: `(f <|> g) <*> x == (f <*> x) <|> (g <*> x)`
- Annihilation: `empty <*> f = empty`
declarations.title: Alternative

declarations.comments:
The `Applicative` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class
with a `pure` function, which can be used to create values of type `f a`
from values of type `a`.

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or
more arguments to functions whose arguments are wrapped using `f`, and
[`Functor`](#functor) provides the ability to lift functions of one
argument, `pure` can be seen as the function which lifts functions of
_zero_ arguments. That is, `Applicative` functors support a lifting
operation for any number of function arguments.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action when a condition is true.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action unless a condition is true.
declarations.title: unless

declarations.comments:
`liftA1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Applicative`](#applicative) functor, without using `(<$>)` as provided
by the [`Functor`](#functor)-[`Applicative`](#applicative) superclass
relationship.

`liftA1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftA1
```
declarations.title: liftA1

declarations.comments:
The `Apply` class provides the `(<*>)` which is used to apply a function
to an argument under a type constructor.

`Apply` can be used to lift functions of two or more arguments to work on
values wrapped with the type constructor `f`. It might also be understood
in terms of the `lift2` function:

```purescript
lift2 :: forall f a b c. Apply f => (a -> b -> c) -> f a -> f b -> f c
lift2 f a b = f <$> a <*> b
```

`(<*>)` is recovered from `lift2` as `lift2 ($)`. That is, `(<*>)` lifts
the function application operator `($)` to arguments wrapped with the
type constructor `f`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Functor`
laws:

- Associative composition: `(<<<) <$> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`

Formally, `Apply` represents a strong lax semi-monoidal endofunctor.
declarations.title: Apply

declarations.comments:
The `Bind` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class with a
"bind" operation `(>>=)` which composes computations in sequence, using
the return value of one computation to determine the next computation.

The `>>=` operator can also be expressed using `do` notation, as follows:

```purescript
x >>= f = do y <- x
             f y
```

where the function argument of `f` is given the name `y`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Associativity: `(x >>= f) >>= g = x >>= (\k -> f k >>= g)`

Associativity tells us that we can regroup operations which use `do`
notation so that we can unambiguously write, for example:

```purescript
do x <- m1
   y <- m2 x
   m3 x y
```
declarations.title: Bind

declarations.comments: Collapse two applications of a monadic type constructor into one.
declarations.title: join

declarations.comments:
Execute a monadic action if a condition holds.

For example:

```purescript
main = ifM ((< 0.5) <$> random)
         (trace "Heads")
         (trace "Tails")
```
declarations.title: ifM

declarations.comments:
The `Monad` type class combines the operations of the `Bind` and
`Applicative` type classes. Therefore, `Monad` instances represent type
constructors which support sequential composition, and also lifting of
functions of arbitrary arity.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`Applicative` and `Bind` laws:

- Left Identity: `pure x >>= f = f x`
- Right Identity: `x >>= pure = x`
- Applicative Superclass: `apply = ap`
declarations.title: Monad

declarations.comments:
`liftM1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<$>)` as provided by the
[`Functor`](#functor)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`liftM1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftM1
```
declarations.title: liftM1

declarations.comments:
`ap` provides a default implementation of `(<*>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<*>)` as provided by the
[`Apply`](#apply)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`ap` can therefore be used to write [`Apply`](#apply) instances as
follows:

```purescript
instance applyF :: Apply F where
  apply = ap
```
declarations.title: ap

declarations.comments:
The `MonadZero` type class has no members of its own; it just specifies
that the type has both `Monad` and `Alternative` instances.

Types which have `MonadZero` instances should also satisfy the following
laws:

- Annihilation: `empty >>= f = empty`
declarations.title: MonadZero

declarations.comments:
Fail using `Plus` if a condition does not hold, or
succeed using `Monad` if it does.

For example:

```purescript
import Prelude
import Control.Monad (bind)
import Control.MonadZero (guard)
import Data.Array ((..))

factors :: Int -> Array Int
factors n = do
  a <- 1..n
  b <- 1..n
  guard $ a * b == n
  pure a
```
declarations.title: guard

declarations.comments:
The `Plus` type class extends the `Alt` type class with a value that
should be the left and right identity for `(<|>)`.

It is similar to `Monoid`, except that it applies to types of
kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types like
`String` or `Number`.

`Plus` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Left identity: `empty <|> x == x`
- Right identity: `x <|> empty == x`
- Annihilation: `f <$> empty == empty`
declarations.title: Plus

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `MonadPlus` type class has no members of its own but extends
`MonadZero` with an additional law:

- Distributivity: `(x <|> y) >>= f == (x >>= f) <|> (y >>= f)`
declarations.title: MonadPlus

declarations.comments:
The `Alt` type class identifies an associative operation on a type
constructor.  It is similar to `Semigroup`, except that it applies to
types of kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types
`String` or `Number`.

`Alt` instances are required to satisfy the following laws:

- Associativity: `(x <|> y) <|> z == x <|> (y <|> z)`
- Distributivity: `f <$> (x <|> y) == (f <$> x) <|> (f <$> y)`

For example, the `Array` (`[]`) type is an instance of `Alt`, where
`(<|>)` is defined to be concatenation.
declarations.title: Alt

declarations.comments:
The `Alternative` type class has no members of its own; it just specifies
that the type constructor has both `Applicative` and `Plus` instances.

Types which have `Alternative` instances should also satisfy the following
laws:

- Distributivity: `(f <|> g) <*> x == (f <*> x) <|> (g <*> x)`
- Annihilation: `empty <*> f = empty`
declarations.title: Alternative

declarations.comments:
The `Applicative` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class
with a `pure` function, which can be used to create values of type `f a`
from values of type `a`.

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or
more arguments to functions whose arguments are wrapped using `f`, and
[`Functor`](#functor) provides the ability to lift functions of one
argument, `pure` can be seen as the function which lifts functions of
_zero_ arguments. That is, `Applicative` functors support a lifting
operation for any number of function arguments.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action when a condition is true.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action unless a condition is true.
declarations.title: unless

declarations.comments:
`liftA1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Applicative`](#applicative) functor, without using `(<$>)` as provided
by the [`Functor`](#functor)-[`Applicative`](#applicative) superclass
relationship.

`liftA1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftA1
```
declarations.title: liftA1

`Apply` can be used to lift functions of two or more arguments to work on


`(<*>)` is recovered from `lift2` as `lift2 ($)`. That is, `(<*>)` lifts

- Associative composition: `(<<<) <$> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`

The `Bind` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class with a

The `>>=` operator can also be expressed using `do` notation, as follows:


Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Apply`

- Associativity: `(x >>= f) >>= g = x >>= (\k -> f k >>= g)`

Associativity tells us that we can regroup operations which use `do`

declarations.title: join

Execute a monadic action if a condition holds.

For example:

```purescript
main = ifM ((< 0.5) <$> random)
         (trace "Heads")
         (trace "Tails")
```
declarations.title: ifM

declarations.comments:
The `Monad` type class combines the operations of the `Bind` and

constructors which support sequential composition, and also lifting of

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`Applicative` and `Bind` laws:

- Left Identity: `pure x >>= f = f x`
- Right Identity: `x >>= pure = x`
- Applicative Superclass: `apply = ap`
declarations.title: Monad

declarations.comments:
`liftM1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<$>)` as provided by the
[`Functor`](#functor)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`liftM1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances

```purescript

  map = liftM1
```
declarations.title: liftM1

declarations.comments:
`ap` provides a default implementation of `(<*>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<*>)` as provided by the

`ap` can therefore be used to write [`Apply`](#apply) instances as
follows:

```purescript

  apply = ap
```
declarations.title: ap

declarations.comments:
The `Plus` type class extends the `Alt` type class with a value that
should be the left and right identity for `(<|>)`.

It is similar to `Monoid`, except that it applies to types of

`Plus` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Left identity: `empty <|> x == x`
- Right identity: `x <|> empty == x`
- Annihilation: `f <$> empty == empty`
declarations.title: Plus

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions

to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```

declarations.comments:
The `MonadZero` type class has no members of its own; it just specifies
that the type has both `Monad` and `Alternative` instances.

Types which have `MonadZero` instances should also satisfy the following
laws:

- Annihilation: `empty >>= f = empty`
declarations.title: MonadZero

declarations.comments:
Fail using `Plus` if a condition does not hold, or
succeed using `Monad` if it does.

For example:

```purescript
import Prelude
import Control.Monad (bind)
import Control.MonadZero (guard)

factors :: Int -> Array Int
factors n = do
  a <- 1..n
  b <- 1..n
  guard $ a * b == n
  pure a
```

declarations.comments:
The `Alt` type class identifies an associative operation on a type
constructor.  It is similar to `Semigroup`, except that it applies to
types of kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types
`String` or `Number`.

`Alt` instances are required to satisfy the following laws:

- Associativity: `(x <|> y) <|> z == x <|> (y <|> z)`
- Distributivity: `f <$> (x <|> y) == (f <$> x) <|> (f <$> y)`

For example, the `Array` (`[]`) type is an instance of `Alt`, where
`(<|>)` is defined to be concatenation.
declarations.title: Alt

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Plus` type class extends the `Alt` type class with a value that
should be the left and right identity for `(<|>)`.

It is similar to `Monoid`, except that it applies to types of
kind `* -> *`, like `Array` or `List`, rather than concrete types like
`String` or `Number`.

`Plus` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Left identity: `empty <|> x == x`
- Right identity: `x <|> empty == x`
- Annihilation: `f <$> empty == empty`
declarations.title: Plus
